title: Anand Panyarachun Prime Minister of Thailand

quotes: Prime Minister of Thailand (1991-1992)
9 August 1932, Bangkok (Thailand)
After completing his education in 1955, Anand joined Thailand’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
In 1958, he was appointed Secretary to the Foreign Minister,
and in 1964 he was assigned to the Permanent Mission of Thailand to the United Nations.
He was promoted simultaneously as the Ambassador of Thailand to the United Nations and as Ambassador of Thailand to Canada in 1967.
In 1972, he was reassigned as Ambassador to the United States in addition to his ongoing post as Ambassador to the United Nations.
His tenure with the United Nations lasted until 1976.
In January 1976, Anand was promoted to the highest Thai civil service ranking as Permanent Minister of Foreign Affairs.
The return of a military-led authoritarian regime in October 1976 led to Anand´s suspension from his position as Permanent Minister,
He retired in 1979, ending his 23 years in the Thai foreign service.
Following the military take-over in February 1991, Anand was invited to serve as Prime Minister of Thailand.
Anand was the first Asian leader to recognize HIV/AIDS as a major development challenge, and he mounted a nation-wide program in 1991 to combat the epidemic in Thailand.

organizations.name: ASEAN
quotes: During his tenure Anand proposed the ASEAN Free Trade Area (AFTA), which was endorsed at the 1991 ASEAN Summit in Singapore.

9 August 1932, Bangkok (Thailand)
After completing his education in 1955, Anand joined Thailand’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Following the military take-over in February 1991, Anand was invited to serve as Prime Minister of Thailand.
He was promoted simultaneously as the Ambassador of Thailand to the United Nations and as Ambassador of Thailand to Canada in 1967.
In 1972, he was reassigned as Ambassador to the United States in addition to his ongoing post as Ambassador to the United Nations.
He was also a catalyst for the 1976 resumption of diplomatic relations with China, Laos and Vietnam.

In January 1976, Anand was promoted to the highest Thai civil service ranking as Permanent Minister of Foreign Affairs.
